awd_abstract_narration:
Graph coloring problems have attracted researchers for more than a century.  This is partially due to their abundant practical applications and their relations to other fields.  For instance, the well-known Four Color Theorem asserts that four colors is always enough to color the regions of a given map such that each region gets one color and two regions sharing some border must receive different colors. This RUI project focuses on intensive research on several graph coloring and choosability problems, which have been frequently used as models for practical applications such as scheduling, traffic control, and the channel assignment problems.  For instance, in scheduling final exam times of all courses at a college, we construct a graph model by representing each course by a vertex, and connecting two vertices (courses) by an edge if a student is taking both courses. The chromatic number of such a graph model provides the minimum number of exam time periods needed in order to schedule all final exams without conflict.  In addition, if some courses set restrictions on certain dates and times, then it becomes a graph choosability problem. Research suitable for undergraduates will be incorporated into Graph Theory and Graduate Seminar courses, providing non-traditional and underrepresented students opportunities to learn cutting edge research methods, and will involve three graduate students yearly to work on research projects.

Graphs provide excellent models for various problems motivated by the channel assignment problem, in which we assign channels to cities or stations such that interference is avoided and the span of channels used is minimized. This RUI project focuses on intensive research on graph coloring and choosability topics with emphasis on utilizing research methodologies and results in number theory, topology, and algebra. The goal is to bring new insight into, and broaden the study of, areas of graph theory that are related to number theory, topology, and algebra, as well as applications to broadcast communication. Specifically, the PI will investigate distance graphs and number theory problems, topological combinatorics, graph choosability, and colorings motivated by the channel assignment problem.

Intellectual Merits: This RUI grant contains four major research topics: 

Topic-1. Distance graphs and number theory problems,

Topic-2. Kneser graphs and topology,

Topic-3. Graph choosability, and

Topic-4. Colorings motivated by the channel assignment problem. 

The results of the published papers in these four topics have made contributions to the respective research areas. The following is a summery of the major outcomes.

Topic-1: Distance graphs and number theory problems

  • The joint paper with then graduate student Grant Robinson, entitled "Sequences With Three Missing Separations," [European Journal of Combinatorics, 2020] has brought new insight into the study of a topic involving problems in number theory (density of sequences with forbidden separations and the parameter involved in the lonely runner conjecture) and graph theory (fractional chromatic number of distance graphs). In particular, we confirmed that the boundary conditions in some earlier results of Haralambis [JCTA, 1977] are sharp. Consequently, our results disclaimed two conjectures of Carraher et al. [Disc. Math., 2016] with counterexamples. 
  • The joint paper with Grant Robinson and Angel Chavez (then undergraduate student), entitled "Distance Graphs Generated by Five Primes," [Advances in Mathematical Sciences, AWM Symposium, Houston, TX, Springer, 2020] extended the results on prime distance graphs studied by Eggleton, Erdos, and Skilton [1990] and by Voigt [four-element prime distance graphs, 1992 and 1999] to five-element prime distance graphs.

Topic-2: Kneser graphs and topology.

  • The joint paper with Xuding Zhu, entitled "A Combinatorial Proof for the Circular Chromatic Number of Kneser Graphs," [Combinatorial Optimization, 2016] provided a simple and combinatorial proof for the circular chromatic number of Kneser graphs. The method is based on results in algebraic topology, but topology background is not required to understand our proof.

Topic-3: Graph choosability.

  • The joint paper with Y. Jiang, D. Liu, Y.-N. Yeh, and X. Zhu, entitled "Colouring of Generalized Signed Triangle-Free Planar Graphs," [Discrete Math,, 2019] proved that for any inverse closed subset S of S_3 which is not isomorphic to {id, (12)}, S is TFP (Triangle-free Planar)-good if and only if either S = {id} or there exists a ∈ {1,2,3} such that for each element g in S, g(a) does not equal to a. It remains an open question to determine whether or not S = {id, (12)} is TFP-good.

Topic-4: Colorings motivated by the channel assignment problems. 

  • The joint paper with L. Saha and Das, entitled "Improved Lower Bounds for the Radio Number of Trees," [Journal of Theoretical Computer Science, 2020] improved the lower bound of the radio number of trees proved by Liu [Discrete Math., 2008] and showed that the new bounds are sharp for infinitely many families of trees included level-wise regular trees (answering an open problem of Halasz and Tuza [Discrete Math., 2015]), and extended results of Bantva, Vaydia and Zhou [Discrete Appl. Math., 2017], and of Li, Mak, Zhou [Discrete Appl. Math., 2015].
  • The joint paper with students Angel Chavez and Mason Shurman (undergraduate), entitled "Optimal Radio-k-Labelings of Graphs," [European Journal of Combinatorics, 2021] extended the current knowledge on radio number of trees to the radio-k-number of trees for general values of k.
  • The joint paper with Devsi Bantva, entitled "Optimal Radio Labellings for Block Graphs and Line Graphs of Trees," [Journal of Theoretical Computer Science, 2021] extended the knowledge on radio labeling for trees to block graphs (graphs whose maximal 2-connected subgraphs are blocks). We proved lower bounds for the radio number of block graphs and showed necessary and sufficient conditions for the bounds to be achieved. We also studied the line graphs of trees (block graphs) and compare the radio number of trees and the radio number of their line graphs.

Broader Impact: During the RUI funding period, the PI has given more than two dozen invited talks and keynote speeches at regional, national or international conferences. Her students have made a total of more than 50 oral or poster presentations.

Besides intensive research with collaborators, the PI has created suitable projects for students to gain research experience. The PI has mentored a total of 10 graduate students and 9 undergraduate students on research projects. Many of the students are from underrepresented groups. The PI supervised these students from reading research articles and making presentations at weekly seminar meetings and at local, state-wide, and national conferences. The students have obtained many awards for their presentations at local, state-wide, and national conferences. The successful valuable experience has turned many novices to budding mathematicians, and inspired many to pursuing advanced degrees. Thus far, five students entered Ph.D. programs and four are applying to. Almost all students have completed an MS degree or are pursuing one.
